  • 使い熟す（こなす）
    • やりこなす：运用自如
  • noun + はおろか = noun + はもちろん：NEGATIVE，不要说前项，就连后项都不行
    • e.g. この辺りはデパートHA愚か、コンビニもない
  • noun + ならまだしも：如果是前项的话那还好，可偏偏是后项
  • どころではない：根本不是
  • に比して（ひして）：compare

27

3000mを超える冬山に、十分な装備もなく単独で登るのは、危険極まりない行為だ。

  • adj词干 +極まりない：very

28

  • noun + を皮切りに　〜　をきかけに：以…为开始做…
  • A や否や　B：A，B几乎同时发生，一。。。就。。
  • A（た）とたんにB：A做之后，B。。。

30

  • たばかり：刚刚做完
  • ばかりに：仅仅因为

31

歯医者「歯を磨く時に、汚れを落とそうとするあまり、強い力で磨いてしまいがちですが、力入れすぎると、歯を傷けてしまいます。優しく磨きましょう」

  • V去ます＋がち：有…倾向
  • あまり：过于
  • 割に：与前项不符合
    • e.g. このホテルは安い割に部屋が広い
  • というと：mentioned about e.g. なぜかというと → 说到为什么

32

  • 名詞A＋ならでは＋名詞：A独有的特色 秋ならではの景色、子供ならではの感性
  • ごとき・ごとく・ごとし＝「名詞」のような

  • 取引先：client
  • 以上は：既然

  • 赤字か：亏钱
  • 図る（はかる）：谋求，策划
  • ノウハウ：know-how、skill、method
  • 以って（もって）：凭借
  • とあってか：正是因为
  • にあって：在…之下 厳しい状況にあって

  • うちから：during/from
  • にしろ：即使也，不论
  • ～てからでないと：不先做前项的话…（就不行）

  • 仕方
    • 〜て仕方がない：非常
    • 〜たくて仕方がない：非常想

  • oral form

    • ちゃ - ては
    • じゃ - では
    • たって - ても
    • だって - でも
    • けど - が
    • くせに - のに
    • とく - ておく
    • どく - でおく
    • もん - もの
    • って - と・と言う

32

  • 〜ている
    • v-ing
    • 持续（动作，状态，习惯/职业，经历/经验）

33

  • 最寄り（もより）：附近，最近
    ! define humble OR honorific: first define WHO DID THIS; then transform the verb to appropriate form

  • formal & humble

    • あげる - 差し上げる：我帮别人
    • もらう - いただく：我请别人帮忙
    • くれる - くださる：别人帮我
    • お見えになる - くる（honorific）
    • あがります - いく（humble）
    • くださいます - くれる（honorific）

34

  • 〜ずにはいられない：忍不住做
  • 〜ないことはない：也不是
  • 〜どころではない：根本顾不上

  • 無理：不可能
  • 無理する：勉强（自己）
  • ものか：表强烈否定

entry.title: 添加「隐藏」/「显示」toggle
entry.content:
最近在准备N1…（苦笑）于是开始进行学语言必备之工作——背单词

想在用博文的形式代替之前记单词用的「Notion」以及「Quizlet」。最主要的原因当然是现阶段成功书写一篇博文所带来的成就感，熟练发博客方法以及养成写作习惯当然也被考虑在内。

于是，在“碰到需要重复记忆的单词怎么办？”这个问题上，便自然地想到了「隐藏」与「显示」的toggle模块。

安装

npm install hexo-sliding-spoiler --save

一些调试

在安装目录下：node_modules/hexo-sliding-spoiler/assets/spoiler.css 找到文件，在25、29行可以更改toggle的提示语（默认为"Show" & “Hide”）。

基本语法

大概就是这样了～ 以后有什么要补充再加～

entry.title: Thoughts on Human Trafficking
entry.content:
Challenges

Such acts are devoid of statistical representations and therefore more widespread than we thought. They are hard to detect, trace, and be penalized because of their victimization and their ontological meaning. Such crime, like other organizational crimes, presents diffuse, delayed, and less reported victimization. First, its victims cannot be categorized into a specific group or a particular individual. Second, victims will notice their predicament mostly at the end of the whole process (or, sadly speaking, at the end of their lives). Based on the reasons above, victims are less likely to report their victimization to law enforcement agencies or the public. Meanwhile, they would also feel shame to tell their experiences and fear reprisals from stakeholders.

Ontologically speaking, such act itself derives from globalization, originated from the interstate system, dominated by profit, facilitated by industrialization, and secured by external forces. Meanwhile, every state all tries to maximize its national interests by circumventing risks, for example, reservations, declarations, and understandings, which would somehow undermine the original purpose of such protocol so that attenuates its efficacy.

Responses

Besides endeavoring in strengthening the interstate corporation among criminal justice systems and caring for victims, the state shall strive for exalting its “local values" under which people would deserve fair distribution of goods. The major reason for human smuggling is poverty. Western countries represent decent lifestyles. Such notion diffused by globalization triggers them to repudiate their current social-economic status, vexing them and finally provoking them into the risk. Therefore, states themselves and the international society should put more effort into providing equal resources facilitating states with economical disparities. Enhancing their local values to increase their confidence and resistance within the surge of globalization.

entry.title: Du Bois -- Veil & Double Consciousness
entry.content:
He accept the difference by race not only the biology diversity but also the socio-cultural variations, rather than forming a color blindness society with race left off the table. However, such difference is not absolute, meaning not “one of a wall”, but rather a membrane-like “veil” with certain interflows allowed. That is also how our society works: we cannot live solely without any interactions with other people. Thus, in the American society, no matter how racial or housing segregation those white supremacists vociferate for, they would not stab their own eyes to ignore the black community. They have to witness the development of black community and culture through which could form their perspective of the world, so does the black people. American society here has formed a subtle balance between these forces. However, this scale has been inclined by the overwhelmingly dominant white mainstream society in the U.S. history, considering the history of slavery and comparably middle and low socio-economical status of black community. As the double-consciousness theory mentioned, black people have both self-consciousness inherited from their blood and from the white-favored social norm, which potentially provide them a need to express or “reintegrate” to the society.

However, one thing noticed here is whether this veil and double-consciousness can be used in other race in the U.S. such as Asian, or in different countries or regions. For example, the double-consciousness between traditional Chinese perspective and the notion from the Briton in Hong Kong. Taiwan also faces the similar issue due to its history and cultural mixture.

Meanwhile, if the notion of double-consciousness and veil did contribute to the BLM movement, why does such movement not occur in other racial communities? Or such double-consciousness and veil are solely discovered in the black community? I need to look up more research to find an answer.

entry.title: Society and Law
entry.content:
Modern Society

  • Industrialization

    • transformation from agrarian to capitalist economy (modern society)

    • capitalist society: working for employer; working for paying manufacture

  • Democratization

    • transformed from ascribed to achieved status, from subject to citizen

    • ascribed: system controlled by blood ( e.g. monocracy )

    • achieved: people getting reward by working

    • characteristics

      • notion of citizenship
      • equal in front of law
      • right to vote
  • Enlightenment
    • scientific method
      • the ability to observe and understand world systematically
      • e.g. death penalty becomes a long process and not only works for deterrence
↑ Law plays a control role in these processes

Society and Law

  • Defining law

    defining law is surprisingly tricky business

    • SHOULD BE DEPEND ON THE CONTEXT OF WHAT YOU ARE INVESTIGATING
    • culture = norms + values
  • Weber: Modern rationalization (rules)

    methodical style of life and set of social attentions

    • Phenomenon
      • organized around the rules, such as tradition, religion, emotion and such forces that motivate human behaviors
      • laws also become rational that replaces oracles, tradition, or emotion to logic and calculation
      • laws also become functionally “isolated” from other institutions like religion or politics
    • Origin: Calvinism
      • Calvinism principle of predestination

      from 16th and early 17th century Calvinist idea of predestination produced an intolerable level of anxiety

      • Calvinists search for signs of being chosen; and they present hard work and accumulation of wealth in response
      • There is a “elective affinity” formed between Calvinism, capitalism and rationalist.
        • nature of law and society evolve together within this elective affinity
  • Durkheim: Collective conscience

    set of shared beliefs ideas and moral attitudes which operate as a unifying force within the society
    idea, norm that bind us in the society

    • Two solidarity
      • mechanical solidarity: simple form of society whose members are culturally bind. When someone commit a crime, the society will repress such behavior and incapacitate offenders. Society with mechanical solidarity emphasizes punishment by passing “repressive law”, because Durkheim thought that repressive sanctions serves important function in maintaining collective conscience and reestablishing boundaries of behaviors (cruel punishment) #punishment
      • organic solidarity: type of society that is more heterogeneous and interdependence. Formed by moral value. Nature of law shifts from repressive to “restitutive” #purpose (criminal sanction → civil sanction)
  • Marx: structuralism

    • Mode of production: from agrarian to capitalism

    • Contract: workers sell their labor power to capitalist (employer).

      ↑ those who own the wealth and those who work to produce it are locked in a conflict of interest

    • Law
      • according to this argument, law are made in order to fulfill the needs of prevailing production systems
      • motor production; materialism;
  • Michel Foucault: “poststructuralism”

    • Power is decentralized and fragmented. Unlike Marxist’s structuralism, power is not an entity applied from the top of the system, but an emergent relation from local social practice among every individuals

    • Discipline and Punishment

      Foucault traces the shift from the gory public executions and torture of convicted criminals in eighteenth-century France to the use of regimented and largely bloodless prisons less than a century later

      ↑ this shift emblems the emergence of modernity; and emphasis on predictability, rationality, dispersion of power/knowledge throughout society, and internalization of discipline by society’s members

    • Poststructuralism highlights the microprocesses of power and the discourse and knowledge that constitute them. Although economic structure is the same important as structuralism in Foucault’s perspective, poststructuralism incorporate the unpredictable elements during our social interaction, knowledge construction, and practice

    Punishment and social control policies are organically linked to sociocultural forces in ways that can be explained after the fact but that are often unpredictable

    • Law → internalize discipline of social members

entry.title: Furman v. Georgia
entry.content:
What may be said of the validity of a law on the books and what may be done with the law in its application do, or may, lead to quite different conclusions

Juries do not intentionally favor the rich, the law is theoretically impartial, but defendant with ample means is able to have his case presented with every favorable aspect while poor defendant often has a lawyer assigned by the court

The very purpose of a Bill of Rights was to withdraw certain subjects from the vicissitudes of political controversy, to place them beyond the reach of majorities and officials and to establish them as legal principles to be applied by the courts
